data.title: Stirnet
data.text: Duncan, Lay Abbot of Dunkeld (d 965) 1. Duncan, Lay Abbot of Dunkeld A. Crinan, Thane, Lay Abbot of Dunkeld (b c975, d 1045) m. (c1000) Bethoc (b 984, d 1045, dau of Malcolm II, King of Scots) i. Duncan I, King of Scots (d 14.10.1040) m. Sybil (dau of Siward, Earl of Northumberland) possibly sister or cousin of Earl Siward a. Malcolm III 'Canmore', King of Scots (b c1031, d Alnwick 13.11.1093) m1. (c1059) Ingibiorg (d before 1070, dau of Finn Arnasson, Jarl of Halland) (1) Duncan II, King of Scots (b 1060, d 12.11.1094) Duncan spent most of his adult life as a hostage in England. With English (ie. Norman) help in 1094 he managed to sieze the throne from his uncle, Donald Bane, but was killed within months. His infant son did not even come into the reckoning as his successor. For a few years Duncan's half-brother Edmund shared the rule (divided the country) with Donald Bane before Edgar was raised to the throne supported by the English and, amongst others, Duncan's son William. m. (c1090) Ethelreda of Northumberland (dau of Gospatrick, Earl of Northumberland, 1st Earl of Dunbar) (A) William FitzDuncan of Skipton, 'Earl of Moray' (d 1154) m. Alice le Meschin (dau of William le Meschin of Copeland) (i) Cicely FitzDuncan, 'Lady of Skipton' m. Guillaume 'le Gros', Count of Aumale, Lord of Holderness (d 20.08.1179) (ii) Amabilis FitzDuncan m. Reginald de Lucie, Governor of Nottingham (a temp Henry II 1154-1189) (iii) Alix or Alice FitzDuncan (d 1215) m1. Gilbert Pipard m2. Margaret, Countess of Orkney (dau of Hakon Paulson, Earl of Orkney) (B) Harald Maddadson, Earl of Orkney & Caithness (b 1134, d 1206) Some sources show his son Heinrick, Earl of Ross, as by his first marriage but this is thought unlikely given that the connection to Ross came through his second marriage. m1. Gospatrick (Cospatrick), Earl of Northumberland, 1st Earl of Dunbar (b c1040, d 1073) GHJRSY d. Maldred of Winlaton (a 1084) (1) Uchtred FitzMaldred (a 1116) It is difficult to distinguish between the various Maldreds, Uchtreds and Cospatricks who were powerful in the north of England around this period, some of whom were related to each other by blood and others by marriage. Initially we showed Dolfin, lord of Raby, as son of Uchtred FitzGospatric on Swinton01. That is shown by (for example) Commoners (vol 2, Nevile of Thorney). We now follow what appears to be the general consensus which is that he fits here. (A) Dolfin, lord of Raby (a 1131) (i) Maldred, lord of Raby (d c1195) (a) Robert FitzMaldred Y (ii) Sir Patric FitzDolfin of Offerton iii. daughter m. Moddan of Dalr, Earl of Caithness (d Thurso 1040) a. Helga Moddandottir JRY m. Hakon Paulson, Earl of Orkney JRY b. Ottar, Earl c. Frakok Moddansdottir
